facts.text: The assessee is a trustee of a house property at Chandmari Road, Howrah.
Title suit filed by Durga Prasad Chamria against Smt. Anardeyi and others claiming title over the property.
Consent decree passed on April 19, 1928: Property belongs to Smt. Anardeyi Sethani but she to pay Rs. 8,61,000/- to plaintiff with compound interest on unpaid amount at 6 3/4% with yearly rests.
Decree payment terms: Rs. 4,25,000/- on execution of settlement, monthly instalments of Rs. 35,000/- for seventeen months, balance in 18th month.
Defaults in payment of interest; terms of compromise not adhered to.
After payment on February 19, 1945, outstanding Rs. 2,70,535/-; simple interest at 6 3/4% for a year: Rs. 18,000/-; assessee calculated compound interest at Rs. 38,221/- for 1956-57.
Assessments relate to assessment years 1956-57 to 1958-59 (accounting years respective calendar years).
Income-tax Officer allowed deduction of Rs. 18,000/- only (simple interest).
Assessee's appeal dismissed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal.
High Court judgments: January 28, 1969 (Income-tax Ref. No. 202 of 1963) and June 13, 1969 (Income-tax Ref. No. 76 of 1968); answered in favour of Department.
Reference question for 1956-57: Whether amount of interest allowable under s.9(1)(iv) was Rs. 18,000/- or Rs. 38,221/-?

legal_issues.text: Whether the assessee was entitled to claim deduction of compound interest under section 9(1)(iv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: The assessee contended that the law permits deduction of any interest paid on the capital borrowed or charged, including compound interest.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 9(1)(iv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

respondent_arguments.text: Only simple interest at 6 3/4% per annum on the capital charge is deductible; compound interest is interest on interest, not on capital charge.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 9(1)(iv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

court_reasoning.text: Section 9(1)(iv) allows deduction of 'the amount of any interest on such mortgage or charge'; interest payable is at 6 3/4% per annum on capital charge; compound interest arises on failure to pay interest, becoming interest on interest, not part of capital charge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real capital charge is original principal; additional interest due to default is not deductible as interest on capital charge.

court_reasoning.text: Accepting assessee's contention would open door for tax evasion by not paying interest regularly and claiming compound interest deduction.

court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee entitled only to simple interest deduction.

holdings.text: Assessee not entitled to deduct compound interest under s.9(1)(iv); only simple interest on capital charge deductible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs deductions for income from property subject to mortgage or capital charge; allows interest on such capital charge but not compound interest on unpaid interest.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed upholding High Court's decision in favour of the Department; assessee not entitled to compound interest deduction.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs, one hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: What the assessee is entitled to deduct is the interest payable by him on the capital charge and not the additional interest which because of his failure to pay the interest on the due date had been considered as a part of the loan.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing simple from compound interest under s.9(1)(iv)

key_quotes.text: If we accept Mr. Chagla's contention as correct, then the door will be open for evasion of tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains policy reason against allowing compound interest deduction
